Graye ⭐ she/her ⭐
A Critical Role sideblog where I can yell about these nerdy ass voice actors and the world they have created to my heart's content. I try to tag 'cr spoilers' until the following Friday. I follow back/reply as pan-galactic-gargle-blast. Banner art is by Anna Landin (annalandin.tumblr.com)!

blog.name: widomauk-week
blog.title: Widomauk Week 2019
blog.description:
Widomauk Week is a week dedicated to the relationship between Mollymauk Tealeaf & Caleb Widogast from Critical Role Campaign 2. Fans of the ship will celebrate in making art, fics, mixes and more with inspiration from prompts & others in the community.

Widomauk Week 2019 will be hosted from June 3rd-June 10th. For more info and prompts, check out the links below!

In the mean time, we'll be sharing people's Widomauk creations here. Feel free to send an ask if you have any questions or suggestions.

twitter: @widomaukweek

blog.title: A Place In The Stars

tags: i trust him as far as i can throw him
summary: Caleb Widogast appears sketchy with his offers of friendship because he himself doesn’t feel genuine about what he’s doing. Liam...
body:
Caleb Widogast appears sketchy with his offers of friendship because he himself doesn’t feel genuine about what he’s doing. Liam said Caleb’s whole thing during the episode was up for interpretation, but he also pointed out that sometimes a person can think “I did that to be genuinely nice” one day then “oh yeah that was all planned” the next.

Maybe that’s Caleb’s internal monologue on everything. One day, he thinks what he’s doing is because of his love for the Mighty Nein, because he actually sees these people as his friends. Then the next day he’ll think this is all just part of his plan, that he needs these people to have his back so he’s gotta butter them up.

There’s a lot Caleb doesn’t trust about himself, and that in turn makes people not trust him so much.

Maybe that’s Caleb’s internal monologue on everything. One day, he thinks what he’s doing is because of his love for the Mighty Nein, because he actually sees these people as his friends. Then the next day he’ll think this is all just part of his plan, that he needs these people to have his back so he’s gotta butter them up.

There’s a lot Caleb doesn’t trust about himself, and that in turn makes people not trust him so much.

blog.name: luckthebard
blog.title: Luck the Bard
blog.description: 30s, Queer (Lesbian), I love D&D; My brother got me hooked on Critical Role. I try but don't always tag spoilers so this account is not #spoilerfree

tags: that Taliesin fellow says really really smart things sometimes :P
he's a wise and insightful pyramid
this was what I was referring to last night when I said I always appreciate his Caleb insight
summary: Something Taliesin said on Talks last night really resonated with me: “With a character that doesn’t...that holds back their...
body:
Something Taliesin said on Talks last night really resonated with me:

“With a character that doesn’t…that holds back their emotional truth, it can be difficult to notice when they’re acting from the heart versus acting tactically. It doesn’t look very different.”

He was talking about Caleb, but I think that’s also just true to life - it’s something we might experience when interacting with people who aren’t keen to expose or showcase their emotions. And I think I’ve experienced the other end of that in my life, where my reluctance or inability to clearly express or expose my emotional truth has led to assumptions that I’m being callous or cold or detached - even about things which I care for deeply.

Just makes me think again about how storytelling, and cooperative storytelling like D&D, can help foster empathy for people who operate in ways we might normally find off-putting, or who we might not understand.

blog.description: I guess I'm super into critical role now: a sideblog

summary: i think the reason ive managed to become so engrossed in critical role so quickly is because its just the right combo of...
body: i think the reason ive managed to become so engrossed in critical role so quickly is because its just the right combo of extremely nerdy, funny, great storytelling, and actual good female characters while also having such a massive amount of content that i can watch for eight hours and have only marginally caught up
